description.narrative: El objetivo del Programa es fortalecer el núcleo de servicios agropecuarios que proveen acceso a la tecnología productiva aplicada correspondiendo a oportunidades del mercado, mientras que reduzcan los riesgos de amenazas a la sanidad agropecuaria y a la inocuidad de alimentos.

The Program objective is to stengthen the core public agricultural services that provide access to applied production technology corresponding to market opportunites, while reducing the risks derived from threats to plant and animal health and food safety. This in turn will contribute to the broader goal to enhance the competitive prodcuteve base upon which Belizeans can increase their incomes.

activity-description.narrative: BAHA’s Officers from the different Departments have attended various workshops both in Belize and internationally, as well as conducted visits with regional bodies responsible for plant and animal health, and food safety. These included visits to Honduras and Panama, workshops in Belize that covered treatment of imported commodities and the collection and identification of insect pests, international symposium on fruit flies of economic importance, an avian influenza workshop in Punta Gorda / Belize, forum in Belmopan / Belize on animal health surveillance, training on the management of food borne disease, attendance at expo in Atlanta, Georgia on the production and processing of poultry. The photo shows participants at the training on collection and identification of insect pests.

BAHA’s Plant Health Department is responsible for protecting Belize from the introduction and spread of regulated pests and for controlling the spread of established pests that may have a negative impact on trade, food security, environment and the natural resource base. The Plant Health Department’s operations cover import regulation, export compliance and general plant protection. BAHA is training its staff in the areas of pest diagnostics and pest risk analysis. In March of 2014 a workshop entitled “Basic Training on Collection and Identification of Insect Pests” was conducted for BAHA Plant Health Officers.

BAHA’s Quarantine Department carries out inspection of imports, goods in transit and verification of exports of agricultural commodities. This ensures compliance with risk-based sanitary and phyto-sanitary requirements, safeguards against the entry and establishment of many pests, diseases and noxious weeds that can compromise our food security, plant, animal and human health and impact negatively on Belize’s economy. In order to inform the general public about the importance of quarantine activities, BAHA set up billboards across the country to emphasize the need to be aware of regulations governing transport of agricultural and food products across the borders.

BAHA’s Quarantine Department installed Distance Diagnostics through Digital Imaging (DDDI) equipment in five quarantine facilities (Central Farm, Benque Viejo Western Border, Santa Elena Northern Border, Big Creek Port, and Punta Gorda). BAHA Officers have been trained to use the equipment.

BAHA’s Quarantine Department is responsible for safeguarding agricultural and human health and food security of Belize by ensuring compliance with sanitary and phyto-sanitary requirements of imported food products and agricultural commodities. Its Quarantine and Inspection Service protects Belize from the introduction of harmful pests and diseases. The Department carries out inspection of imports, transits and verification of exports of agricultural commodities. The workshop was conducted by experts from the Regional and International Organization for Agricultural Health (OIRSA).

BAHA’s Quarantine Facility / Office in Placencia has been upgraded to provide adequate space for personnel and equipment. This forms a part of BAHA’s network of quarantine facilities throughout the country.

Incinerators are required at port of entries to ensure an effective quarantine program is being implemented. Six facilities for the incinerators have been refurbished in Punta Gorda, Placencia, Benque Viejo Western Border, Belize City (Central Investigative Laboratory), Philip Goldson International Airport, and Santa Elena Northern Border.

Incinerators are required at port of entries to ensure an effective quarantine program is being implemented. Six incinerators have been installed in Punta Gorda, Placencia, Benque Viejo Western Border, Belize City (Central Investigative Laboratory), Philip Goldson International Airport, and Santa Elena Northern Border and are operational.

One of BAHA’s strategic goals is to enhance protection, improve service delivery, and increase awareness of its public good function. In this context BAHA conducted activities to inform the general public about the importance of quarantine activities, and how these activities help to ensure the safety of Belize’s food supply. In connection with these activities a booth was set up at the annual National Agricultural and Trade Show in Belmopan to inform the thousands in attendance about the work that BAHA performs.

The Agricultural Services Program’s objective is to strengthen the effectiveness of core public agricultural health services that provide access to applied production technology corresponding to market opportunities, while reducing the risks derived from threats to plant and animal health and food safety. To operational guidelines for a Competitive Grant Scheme have been developed through the NCCARD.

The Agricultural Services Program’s objective is to strengthen the effectiveness of core public agricultural health services that reduce the risks derived from threats to plant and animal health and food safety. To this end, twenty-five Extension Service Officers of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Agriculture received training in research and development.

The Agricultural Services Program’s objective is to strengthen the effectiveness of core public agricultural health services that reduce the risks derived from threats to plant and animal health and food safety. To this end, the Central Farm Research Station has been strengthened with agricultural equipment for research and development.

This program supports the strengthening of research and development and extension activities conducted by the Central Farm Research Station to ensure that Belizean producers benefit from new agricultural innovation results. The funding provided for agriculture machinery and equipment to be used by the Crop, Livestock and Agro-processing division as well as office furniture for National Coordinating Committee for Agriculture Research and Development (NCCARD)

This program supports the strengthening of research and development and extension activities conducted by the Central Farm Research Station to ensure that Belizean producers benefit from new agricultural innovation results. The funding provided for agriculture machinery and equipment to be used by the Crop, Livestock and Agro-processing division as well as office furniture for National Coordinating Committee for Agriculture Research and Development (NCCARD).
